Cope, South Carolina 29038

Orangeburg County



COPE STATION EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

                              

OVERVIEW



Cope Station is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, contractors, the surrounding community, and the environment.  To meet this commitment, Cope Station has established systems to ensure safe operation of plant processes, which includes the safe and proper handling of hazardous substances at the plant.  One component of these systems is a Risk Management Program (RMP), which manages the risks involved with using hazardous substances.  Cope Station has designed this program to control and reduce the risk of injury, death, environmental damage, or property damage as well as being a teaching aid for employees to learn how their job is an integral part of the RMP process.  The program protects employees, contractors and the public. 

 

Cope Station's RMP complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) regulation 40 CFR  68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs.  This regulation is also referred to as "the RMP rule".  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit an executive summary in the Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) describing the RMP at Cope Station.  This document is intended to satisfy the executive summary requirement of the RMP rule and to provide a description of the RMP.  



The Cope Station Power Plant is located at 405 Teamwork Road, Cope, South Carolina in the County of Orangeburg.  The power plant generates 430 megawatts of electricity from pulverized coal.

The Cope Station Power Plant operates a Selective Catalytic Reactor (SCR) to lower its total Nitrogen Oxide (NOx) emissions.  The SCR process utilizes anhydrous ammonia to react with the NOx compounds, converting the NOx into nitrogen (an inert gas) and water vapor.  This process necessitates the storage of large

quantities of ammonia (> 10,000 lbs) to support operation of the SCR.  The RMP program is initiated when a facility stores 10,000 lb. or more of anhydrous ammonia.  The Cope Station Power Plant is rated a Program 3 facility.



Although the RMPlan helps ensure that Cope Station's RMP covered system is maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of the plant's overall safety program.  In fact, a comprehensive safety program exists that establishes many levels of safeguards against accidents.



CONSIDERATIONS



Limiting the use of substances regulated by the RMP rule:



DESC did perform a thorough evaluation before selecting a pollution control technology that uses

a hazardous substance regulated by the RMP rule ("regulated substance").  The potential for the

hazardous substance to affect individuals and the environment has been considered, and DESC has

taken the appropriate steps to address the hazards.





Preventing releases of the regulated substances used:



When a regulated substance is used, the equipment that contains it is carefully designed, built, and

operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release.  All applicable federal, state, corporate,

and industry standards are strictly adhered to in the design, construction, and operation of the

equipment.





Limiting damage from a release, if such a release occurs:



Cope Station's main objective is to prevent the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from occurring.  In the analysis administrative controls (written procedures), high level alarms will limit the maximum volume of stored anhydrous ammonia to 85% tank capacity. The worst-case release scenario was identified to be a rupture of one of the storage tanks.  The result of this scenario was modeled using RMPCOMP.    



In the unlikely event of a release, employees are trained to recognize accidental releases quickly, assess the severity of a release and respond to mitigate and stop the release. Coordination

with the county's Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) is crucial to protect the health and safety of the surrounding community.  







The DESC safety program consists of several elements, many of which are beyond what is required by the RMP rule.  This RMPlan Executive Summary is written to describe only those parts of the safety program required by the RMP rule for Cope Station.



ELEMENTS



1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



DESC is committed to the safety of its employees and contractors, the public, and to the protection of the environment. The anhydrous ammonia at Cope Station is stored in two tanks. The two storage tanks are located inside a concrete secondary containment dike to limit the spread of liquid ammonia in case of a tank rupture.  All appropriate steps have been taken to prevent the accidental release of

anhydrous ammonia.  These steps include (a) training programs for personnel, (b) programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process, and (c) programs

to evaluate the hazards of our processes.



In the event of an accidental release, DESC will be prepared to respond in a manner that will be safe for our employees and will minimize any injury to the public and the environment.  The plant

has a trained and equipped Emergency Response Team on site.  The planning efforts performed in conjunction with Orangeburg County Emergency Management Department (LEPC) will help ensure proper coordination of emergency response personnel.





2.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE USED AT DESC COPE STATION



Cope Station has one substance (anhydrous ammonia) in sufficient quantity to be regulated by the RMP rule.  The anhydrous ammonia used at the plant is covered as a toxic material by the RMP rule.  As stated previously, anhydrous ammonia will be used as a reactant to reduce the emission of NOx from the plant.





3.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREV

ENTION STEPS



DESC has developed a comprehensive prevention program that complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation (OSHA 1910.119).  For Cope Station, the prevention program requirements of EPA's RMP rule are also satisfied by this PSM program.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of our prevention program that address the RMP rule requirements.



3.1   Accidental Release Prevention Program



The accident prevention program for anhydrous ammonia consists of the following 12 elements:



3.1.1   Process Safety Information



A number of technical documents are maintained and are readily available at the plant, including an emergency preparedness plan to help ensure that plant and local emergency responders are aware of the hazards.  These documents address (a) physical properties of anhydrous ammonia, (b) operating parameters for the equipment, and (c) design basis and configuration for the equipment.  This process safety information is available to our employees and contractors, as well.



3.1.2   Process Hazard Analysis



Process Hazard Analysis of the anhydrous ammonia process was performed and will be periodically updated to identify process hazards, as well as to establish recommendations that will improve the safe operation of the RMP covered process.  This analysis is revised at least every 5 years to ensure it is current.



3.1.3   Operating Procedures 



Cope Station's engineers, operators, and the Plant Manager worked together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to the ammonia system operations should be safely performed.  The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and process upsets.  Operating procedures include:



? Steps for safely conducting activities.

? Applicable safety information, such as safety operating limi

ts and consequence of deviations.

? Safety and health considerations, such as chemical hazards, personal protective equipment requirements, and actions to take if exposure to a hazardous substance occurs.

   

3.1.4    Training



Employees are trained to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  The training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers (a) a general overview of the system, (b) the    properties and hazards of anhydrous ammonia, and (c) a detailed review of the operating procedures and safe work practices.  Classroom training and demonstrations are used to help impart knowledge to the employees.  Tests and demonstrations are used to verify that an employee understands the training material before the employee can work on the anhydrous ammonia system.



3.1.5   Mechanical Integrity



The anhydrous ammonia handling equipment is maintained to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger employees and contractors, the public, or the environment. The mechanical integrity (preventive maintenance) program includes (a) an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage well before the equipment can fail and (b) a quality assurance function to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meet the strict design standards required for service in our process.



3.1.6   Management of Change



The Management of Change procedure is a written procedure that requires the review and approval of all proposed changes to the anhydrous ammonia system.  This includes chemicals, equipment, technology, and procedures to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations.  All changes other than replacement-in-kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) must be approved through the Management of Change procedure.  This helps to ensure that inadvertent consequences of changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety informat

ion and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.



3.1.7   Pre-startup Safety Review



Safety reviews of new or modified processes are performed before placing them into service to help ensure their safe operation.  This review confirms that:



?    Construction activities and equipment are in accordance with design specifications;

?    adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place;

?    employee training has been completed; and

?    for a covered process ("regulated process"), a Process Hazard Analysis has been performed if the process is new, or management of change requirements have been completed if an existing process has been modified.

   

3.1.8    Compliance Audit



One of the cornerstones of an effective prevention program is a regular, thorough assessment.  A program is in place to perform compliance audits of our RMP-covered processes every 3 years to be certain the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the process.  These audits are performed by an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the PSM and RMP regulations and in our process designs, and this team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of these two regulations and whether it is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the ammonia system.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.



3.1.9   Incident Investigation



A program is in place to investigate any incidents or near misses that could reasonably result in serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented in the future.  The requirements to identify and report any incident requiring investigation are communicated to employees.  In the event of an incident, an investigation team would be assembled, and the investigation would be initiated as soon as possib

le, but always within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process improvements are implemented.



3.1.10   Employee Participation



A written employee participation program exists for our RMP covered process to help ensure that the safety concerns of our employees are addressed.  We encourage active participation of personnel in the prevention program activities of all processes at the plant.  Employees are consulted and informed about all aspects of our accidental release prevention program.



3.1.11 Hot Work Permits



A Hot Work Permit Program exists, which is intended to control spark or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions at Cope Station.  This program conforms to OSHA requirements.  Training on hot work activities and on the requirements of the hot work permit program is included in our new employee orientation.

   

3.1.12   Contractors



A program is in place to help ensure that contractor activities related to the RMP covered ammonia system are performed in a safe manner.  Contractor supervisors are informed of the hazards of the processes on which they and their employees will work, our safe work practices, and our emergency response procedures.  Contractors are required to ensure that training has been performed for each of their employees before he/she performs work at the plant.  Routine verification that this training has been provided is performed.





3.2   Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



In addition to the required prevention program elements, safety features specific to the anhydrous ammonia process have been implemented.



The anhydrous ammonia is delivered in tank trucks that must be approved by the Department of Transportation.  The plant's anhydrous ammonia storage tank and equipment are designed and

maintained to standards established by the federal government and by industry.  Manual shutoff valves, excess flow d

evices in the storage tank, and ammonia detectors with alarms are provided as

process controls to help prevent or mitigate releases of anhydrous ammonia from the system.





4.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no recordable releases of anhydrous ammonia within the last five years.  The anhydrous ammonia system has been designed to codes and standards that were established to minimize the possibility of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia from the system that could result in exposure to employees, contractors, the public, or the environment.





5.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS



The emergency response plan provides the contact name and phone number of the Orangeburg County Emergency Management department (LEPC) as well as the phone numbers of the local fire department, hospital, police station and a hazardous waste response company to assist the company emergency response team on an as needed basis.  The plan also includes the following information:

?    Proper first aid and emergency medical treatment procedures to treat accidental human exposure to anhydrous ammonia.

?    Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.

?    Procedures for the use, inspection, testing and maintenance of emergency response equipment.

?    Training for employee's response during an accidental spill.

?    Procedures to review and update the emergency response plan.

?    Coordination with the LEPC.



Employees are trained to recognize, and report known, or even perceived, emergency situations. Employees and contractors are trained in evacuation procedures.  The county LEPC (Orangeburg

County Emergency Management Department) is responsible for notifying the public of the emergency situation and coordinating with other public safety agencies and LEPCs, if necessary.







6.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



DESC is committed to continuous improvement of the "safety process" using recommendations developed through the prevent

ion program and a program soliciting safety suggestions from our employees.  Standard operating and safety procedures for the RMP covered process are reviewed periodically to ensure that they are correct, and training is provided to employees on a wide variety of safety and operating topics.
